title: Camera in video calls does not work
content:
Hello everyone! I’m writing to asking for help about an issue with the camera not working on Mozilla Firefox during video calls. When I try to join a Google Meet session, I receive a message asking me to grant camera permissions - even though the permissions are already enabled both in the browser and my computer’s settings.

Interestingly, the camera works perfectly fine on other browsers like Google Chrome, so the issue seems to be specific to Firefox. I’ve already checked the following:

- Camera permissions are all allowed for Google Meet in Firefox; - The system settings (Windows) permit Firefox to access the camera; - No other applications are blocking the camera. I know that 'cause I'm using this camera on WhatsApp and TikTok Live Studio.

Could y'all please help me resolve this? I’d appreciate any troubleshooting steps or fixes you can provide.

PS.: The images are written in portuguese. But it's all how I told you before.

content:
I’m on Windows (latest updates) and using the most recent version of Firefox. Whenever I try to play YouTube videos, they either buffer indefinitely or won’t load at all. I’ve already tried: 

   Clearing cache and cookies 
   Disabling all add-ons and extensions 
   Toggling hardware acceleration 
   Creating a new Firefox profile 
   Uninstalling and reinstalling Firefox from scratch 
   Checking DRM settings (Widevine) 
   Updating my graphics drivers 
   Temporarily disabling antivirus/firewall 
   Flushing DNS and trying a different DNS

None of these steps solved the problem. YouTube works fine in other browsers on the same system. I’d appreciate any suggestions or help to fix this. Thank you!

title: Playing 11xplay Online Without a Budget When Playing on.
content: 11xplay online, budgeting is very important, but many players don't do it. You can avoid spending more than you can afford to lose by creating a budget. It's easy to get carried away by the excitement, but setting a limit helps keep gaming fun and responsible. Your future self will be grateful that you adhered to your budget rather than chasing losses. A Dangerous Move on 11xplay Online: Chasing Losses Pursuing Losses are one of the most dangerous online gaming behaviors. Players frequently attempt to recoup their losses by placing larger wagers. This tactic is rarely successful and may result in even greater losses. On 11xplay online, you should take a break, reevaluate your strategy, and come back with a new perspective rather than chasing losses. ignoring game strategies when playing11xplay Online On 11xplay online, some games rely solely on luck, while others require skill and planning. Learning the fundamental strategies of poker, blackjack, and even some slot games can increase your chances of winning. There are a lot of players who jump right in without doing any research into strategies, missing out on opportunities to win more.

title: Firefox reuses window object on same-origin iframe?
content:
I created a new iframe and added a new value in its contentWindow, and changed the src of the iframe like below.

``` (() => { 

 const frame = document.createElement('iframe');  document.body.appendChild(frame);  frame.contentWindow.testASDF = 'TEST_VAR';  frame.src = 'http://localhost:5500/test/iframe.html'; 
 setTimeout(() => console.log('testASDF: ', frame.contentWindow.testASDF), 3000); // I expect 'undefined', but 'TEST_VAR' printed.

})(); ```

I thought the 'testASDF' value would be gone after the iframe loaded the new src, but the value I set remaining even after the iframe loaded anew. In Chrome, it's not reproduced.

It only happens when I set a same-origin iframe src and modify the src synchronously with the line above. For example, the script below doesn't reproduce the problem.

``` (async () => { 

 const sleep = (ms) => new Promise((res) => setTimeout(res, ms)); 
 const frame = document.createElement('iframe');  document.body.appendChild(frame);  frame.contentWindow.testASDF = 'TEST_VAR';  await sleep(1); // asynchronous routine added  frame.src = 'http://localhost:5500/test/test.html'; 
 setTimeout(() => console.log('testASDF: ', frame.contentWindow.testASDF), 3000);

})(); ```

Is this a bug or optimization of Firefox?

UA: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.15; rv:137.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/137.0
creator: 5kyc1ad

Chrome works fine. I'm using it (unfortunately) now in order to contact you.

When using FIrefox, it starts and does some partial loading, but then stops responding. On the default Firefox startup, about 1/2 of the "thought provoking story" pictures load. If I go directly to Youtube, for example, again....it starts loading then "hangs".

I can't close Firefox either: the window closes, but it's still running. If I attempt to restart it after closing, I get a "Firefox still running" error (which also won't close it.) Windows task manager will shut down the 5-10 (it varies) Firefox processes.

Tried checking for updates. That also gets stuck trying (let it try for about 10 minutes). Don't see any "reinstall" option.

Tried "Refresh Firefox" (fails....Firefox won't close). Tried "Clear startup Cache)" (same) Tried "Troubleshooting Mode)" (same)

Should I delete it and download again?
creator: d.e.wickson
